item.title: Sheril Kirshenbaum
item.description: What the dystopia?Virginia School Board attorneys argued that Abigail Zwerner - the 1st grade teacher shot in her classroom by a 6yo - is not entitled to more than worker‚Äôs compensation bc the shooting was ‚Äúa workplace injury‚Äù & ‚Äúhazard of the job.‚Äùhttps://www.denverpost.com/2023/05/03/educators-outraged-teacher-shot-in-school-workplace-injury/

item.title: Thesiswhisperer
item.description: This is the last day of my Twitter account. I have over 52K followers there, but I can't remain on a platform that pays people like Andrew Tate to post. I do this knowing it significant limits my reach in the academic community, but the standard you walk past is the one you accept.

item.title: Craig Hockenberry
item.description: @jkottke Same. I do this on every Mac I own: https://furbo.org/2015/03/30/paste-without-style/

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Very interesting essay from Stuart Buck, who was an important facilitator for PubPeer, both for channelling funding from the LJAF, but also for an introduction to the ACLU when we were subpoenaed by Fazlul Sarkar. Mostly unrelated to PubPeer, it's amazing to relive the squealing, in fact downright vicious, entitlement of psychologists whose experiments did not replicate.https://goodscience.substack.com/p/metascience-since-2012-a-personal

item.title: Joshua Foust üéÆ
item.description: Just had a reviewer use Dan Ariely‚Äôs work on dishonesty to say that my interpretation of public sphere and public relations literature was off. I was like, THE Dan Ariely, the now infamous data fabricator? And yes - they rejected the paper because it didn‚Äôt align with a fake book. Academic publishing is WILD, y‚Äôall

item.title: El Duvelle Neuro
item.description: Hi all! My first "neuro-focused" post üß†‚Äã has to be these beautiful #PlaceCells that I recorded in a #NeuroRat foraging for cocops in a rectangle. #Hippocampus #NeuroForNewbies ‚è¨‚Äã(trying this out)What are "place cells"? They are a category of neurons, first discovered in the brain of rats, that activate only in specific locations in a given environment. Each place cell fires at a different location, together forming a sort of map (#CognitiveMap) of all the locations that we know.plot legend is described in the alt-text(Edit: added hippocampus tag)

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
#neuroscience
This is an important discussion imo. If people are unhappy with J Neuroscience perhaps this could be communicated to Sabine Kastner, I'm sure it's would be valuable information. I really liked the journal btw.
Plos Biol is another good option but very selective no??
@cogneurophys

item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description:
@BorisBarbourMoving to the UK, as a scientist:Startup package, what‚Äôs that?
Entry-level faculty salary lower than your postdoc salary a decade ago, what do you mean?
Child care as expensive as elsewhere where salaries are twice the amount, that can‚Äôt possibly be, right?
Buying a house costs several times the cost of a house where you lived before, come on that can‚Äôt be that bad?
Ah yes, please pay many thousands of pounds upfront so that we can sign you up with the NHS‚Ä¶ no we can‚Äôt finance that or let you pay it over multiple months.
We hope you can still apply to the ERC, the local funding bodies are overstretched but surely it will work out?In other words, please subsidise us from your savings and international collaborations.This is not a red carpet but a tar pit with snakes, flying arrows and a giant rolling stone catching up to your footsteps.#uk #academia

item.title: Marc Elias
item.description: The myth that citizens can out-organize voter suppression is not just wrong, it is dangerous. It minimizes the real world effects of repeated, targeted suppression laws. It shifts the burden from the suppressors to the voters. https://www.democracydocket.com/opinion/we-cannot-out-organize-voter-suppression/

item.title: Dan Birman
item.description: #introduction post!I'm Dan - I started building interactive 3D tools for #neuroscience this year. So far, I've built a neuropixels planning tool https://github.com/VirtualBrainLab/Pinpoint and a python API for rendering exploratory data visualizations that involve the mouse brain https://github.com/VirtualBrainLab/Urchin. Currently a postdoc @ UW Get in touch if you think about science data visualization, I'm looking for ideas for the next great tool to contribute to or start building!
